clues.text: Mehmed VI, the last sultan of this empire, was forced to abdicate in 1922, paving the way for Kemal  Atat√ºrk
This Russian czar renounced the throne March 15, 1917 & was killed with his family a year later
In 2013 at age 85, he became the first pope to abdicate since Gregory XII in 1415
He became Japan's 126th emperor on May 1, 2019 after his father Akihito abdicated due to advancing age
This country's King Norodom Sihanouk abdicated twice: in 1955 in favor of his father & in 2004 in favor of his son
In 2002 an ankylosaurus species was named after this author of a dino-mite 1990 novel
The team overseeing the Curiosity rover named a "landing" after this author of "The Martian Chronicles"
Found in the name of a bewitching Disney show with Selena Gomez, this street or "Place" in NYC was named for a Walter Scott novel
A species of fish with a long snout is named for this character with a big ol' nose from an 1897 play
A type of trapdoor spider with blue eyes has this spicy fictional desert planet in its name
Sugars or starches--keep 'em low in a keto diet
It's a quick way to say you want, say, the 2021 Caymus Vineyards with its notes of black cherry
Short for your longtime pal, it first appeared pre-WWII; it's also D. name of a clown in an "In Living Color" sketch
In the streets it's your rival; Maxo Kream rhymes the word with "drop"
Iivestrong.com notes it's better to relax your chest & then twitch the muscle under your collarbone to make these fellas bounce
There are this many officially recognized constellations, same as the number of keys on a standard piano
In 2024 West Conshohocken Borough in Pennsylvania celebrated its sesquicentennial, this many years
4,189 (hits) & 2,130 (consecutive games) fell, but this hitting streak by Joe DiMaggio endures
General Sherman's special field orders, No. 15 reserved land for freed families in tracts of up to this many acres
As the word for this number sounds like it means "certainly death", Cantonese speakers have a collective case of tetrakaidekaphobia
The title of Stevie Wonder's song "Sir Duke" references this member of music nobility
In 1961 Stevie was introduced to Berry Gordy, founder of this record label, & many of his albums were issued by its Tamla subsidiary
Stevie wanted to add a Swahili phrase on this charity single, causing Waylon Jennings to bail (good ole boys don't sing in Swahili)
Stevie's music evoked the circus for Smokey Robinson, who wrote the lyrics for what became this hit for Smokey & The Miracles
Title line that precedes "That's why I'll always stay around, you are the apple of my eye, forever, you'll stay in my heart"
clues.response: you are the sunshine of my life

clues.text: Jacques-Pierre Brissot went to America to help the antislavery cause, then back to Paris to get its keys after it was stormed
This explorer may have been to Brazil in the early 16th century before going west again, giving Canada its name on a later trip
Philosopher Jacques Derrida was born in this African country when it was governed by France, but left for Paris in 1949
In 1960 Don Walsh & Jacques Piccard went to this spot in the Pacific, the deepest place on Earth
This Prussian-born French composer took a trip to the underworld with his 1858 opera about Orpheus
Braincase
The trachea
The laryngeal prominence
The coccyx
Hallux
These Christians who take the Bible quite literally, without "amen"
This type of covenant, limiting how you can use your property, without "strict"
This word for a type of attachment to an item from your past, without "time"
This past tense verb meaning "cried out for", as in "the crowd ____ for an encore", without "more"
This, which roughly 1/4 of Americans experience each year, without "omni" (not exactly a plug for the hotel chain)
Joyce Kilmer wrote, "I think that I shall never see a poem lovely as" this
Jean Toomer wrote of the flower of this crop, "Boll-weevil's coming, and the winter's cold"
"The New Colossus" mentions "a mighty woman" with one of these "whose flame is the imprisoned lightning"
The last stanza of John Keats' poem about this title object mentions its "Attic shape"
Oliver Wendell Holmes wrote of this, "Her deck once red with heroes' blood, where knelt the vanquished foe"
It's the "national" name for the kids' game with 2 jump ropes turning in opposite directions
This synonym for "lasso" comes from the Spanish reata, meaning rope
Boxing legend Archie Moore called a defense "the turtle shell"; Muhammad Ali adapted it to what he called this
Clove & half are 2 of these knots used to tie a rope to a post or other support
Tensions between rope makers & British soldiers helped lead to a March 1770 shooting of civilians in this city
"Tampopo", about a woman's adventures in her noodle shop in this country, has been called a "Ramen Western"
Eva Longoria directed 2023's "Flamin' Hot", about Richard Montanez, who claims to have invented these flamin' hot snacks
Dishes made by Remy, an animated gourmand of the garbage, include an omelet, a roasted mushroom & this title dish
As Harold & Kumar in a 2004 film can attest, this fast food chain hits different after riding a cheetah & hang gliding
At the start of this 1973 sci-fi film, Edward G. Robinson wants more of the title food; by the end, he becomes the title food
The 48-gun galleon San Martin was the flagship of the Duke of Medina Sidonia, who led this group against England in 1588
This ironclad built by John Ericsson for the U.S. Navy was never truly seaworthy & sank in December 1862 off Cape Hatteras
The world's largest aircraft carrier for 10 years, it was built starting in October 1943 & named for a battle 16 months before
In 1789 this ship's crew tried to settle on Tubuai in the Austral Islands but were rebuffed by the native inhabitants & returned to Tahiti
This similar-sounding sister ship of the Lusitania named for a North African kingdom served as a hospital ship in World War I

rounds.text: A U.S. Navy website says its journey from New London to Norway in 1957 opened up Arctic waters previously ruled by the Soviets
